Looking for WET v3.1?

WET v4.0 is now the current version. There is a new location for the Getting started page in WET v3.1.

Getting Started with the Web Experience Toolkit

Follow these quick steps to understand how to get started using the Web Experience Toolkit on your own site to create usable, accessible, mobile-friendly websites and applications. Before you get started, discover which variants are available in the Web Experience Toolkit. Start by choosing a flexible theme. Then find the components that meet your content needs. Finally, customize display elements such as buttons and icons.

  • 1Choose a themeThere are five themes to choose from. You define the look and feel of your website through the cascading style sheet (CSS). If you are using a content management system, then you can find more information in variants.

    Base theme

    A Base theme template for creating your own theme.

    Download Base theme

    Canada.ca theme

    Mandatory theme for Canada.ca users only. It implements requirements for Canada.ca

    Download Canada.ca theme

    Intranet theme

    Built by the community for the community, open for re-use and adapting.

    Download Intranet theme

    Usability theme

    This theme implements the Standards of Web Usability.

    Download Usability theme

    WET theme

    In use on this site, this theme is an example of how the base theme can be easily changed.

    Download WET theme
  • 2Components The Toolkit contains reusable components to add interactive and accessible features to your site such as widgets, form validation, navigation menus, web feeds, and many more.

    Plug-ins

    Each plug-in adds functionality by calling the function in the class attribute of an HTML tag.

    Featured Plug-in: Lightbox gallery

    When a user clicks on, selects or holds the image, the photo gallery opens in a fullscreen lightbox where they can view the images one by one.

    Learn more

    Polyfills

    Polyfills are JavaScript components that mimic the behaviour of HTML5 tags in browsers in order to provide backwards compatibility for browsers that do not support HTML5.

    Featured polyfill: datalist (auto-complete)

    For example, when a user types a V into a field called City, all cities beginning with V will appear in the text box.

    Learn more
  • 3Design elementsThis guide explains how to design front-end elements of your website by changing the cascading style sheet (CSS). Let the magic begin!

    Core design elements

    Here are some reusable and customizable design elements that you can use in designing your website. You can find more design elements in the design guide. For all other guides, go to web guides.

    • Buttons
    • Sizing
    • Alignment
    • Alerts
    • Grids
    • Lists
    • Forms
    • Images

    Featured example: alert box

    Well done!

    You successfully read this important alert message.

    Provide contextual feedback messages for typical user actions with the handful of available and flexible alert messages.

    Learn more
